sentence: To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

(A) The clinical “optic disc” (or “papilla”) and “peripapillary” regions are defined relative to the clinical disc margin (Figure 1). (B) We propose that OCT evaluation of the ONH tissues should be organized relative to the OCT-detected neural canal and the Foveal-BMO axis (see Figures 3 and 4).

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

Descriptions of Panels A through H are the same for both the healthy control and highly myopic eyes. (A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4).

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42
Figure 4.
FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

Within the 3D point cloud of segmented points from each OCT ONH data set, (Figure 3), Bruch’s membrane and the anterior scleral surface points were interpolated using b-splines. pNC-CT was assessed in microns at six distances (vertical blue dotted lines) from the ASCO, measured within the ASCO reference plane, (horizontal blue dotted line).
To simplify data presentation, we concentrate on pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points (where they approximate the measurement of pNC-SS (see Figure 5).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

ICC values for the sectoral pNC-SB and pNC-CT parameters ranged from moderate to excellent (.51 to 0.99) (mean ± SD 0.92 ± 0.11), however pNC-SB-SS (0- 300 μms) values for the superior-nasal (0.23) and nasal-superior sectors (0.46) (Figure 4) were poor.Highly myopic versus control Comparisons
pNC-SB was increased and pNC-CT was decreased in the highly myopic compared to control eyes and these increases and decreases were greatest in the inferior and inferior temporal quadrant sectors.
Plots of eye-specific, global data versus age for the pNC-SB and CT parameters are reported in Figure 8.

Bold - P ≤ 0.05
Mean sectoral values for all pNC-SB and pNC-CT parameters are reported for control and highly myopic eyes in Figure 9.
Within the control and highly myopic groups, the pCT values in the thickest pNC-CT sectors were significantly thicker than the thickness values in lowest pNC-CT sectors (Figure 9).

For pNC-CT1100, choroidal thickness in the thinnest sectors was significantly thinner in the highly myopic compared to the control eyes.Sectoral pNC-SB is not related to sectoral pNC-CT in the control eyes, but is inversely related to sectoral pNC-CT in the highly myopic eyes. (Figure 10).
Data for the pNC-SB-ASCOD versus pNC-CT 1100 comparison is representative of all comparisons and is reported here and shown in Figure 10.

Maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-SB were increased and maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-CT were decreased within the inferior sectors of the highly myopic with GLVFL compared to the highly myopic without GLVFL eyes (Supplemental Figure 1) but these differences did not achieve statistical significance.

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).
Clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, FoBMO visualization of pNC-SB and pNC-CT data for the healthy control (upper) and highly myopic (lower) eyes shown in Figure 3.

FoBMO orientation of the data is achieved by rotating the photo (8° counter clock-wise above and 10° clockwise below) so that the FoBMO axis, rather than the Acquired Image Frame ((AIF) - Blue outline –Figure 4), establishes the Nasal-Temporal and Superior-Inferior axes (shown for the healthy control eye, above, red dotted lines). (B) pNC-SB-ASCOD data for each eye schematically presented in eye-specific, (left eye above and right eye, below) FoBMO orientation. (C) pNC-SB-SS data for the inner (0-300), middle (300-700) and outer (700-1000) measurement segments presented schematically in FoBMO orientation. (D) Continuously plotted pNC-SB-SS data in FoBMO orientation. (E) and (F) pNC-CT data presented schematically (E) and continuously (F) relative to the FoBMO axis.

Note that while the sectoral differences in pNC-CT data are modest for the control eye (upper) and substantial for the highly myopic eye (lower), by inspection of the sectoral values, the inferior temporal regions demonstrate the greatest amount of pNC-SB and the thinnest pNC-CT for both the control and highly myopic eye.Figure 12.
Figure 11 illustrates how both pNC-SB and pNC-CT can be topographically mapped on the infrared (IR) fundus image acquired at the time of OCT imaging.

However, to know if either eye demonstrates sectoral values that are outside of normative values requires eye- specific structural abnormality detection as shown in Figure 12 is required.Clinically-intuitive, topographically correspondent, myopic and glaucomatous structural abnormality detection relative to the FoBMO axis.

Figure 12 illustrates our conceptual framework for clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, structural abnormality detection in non-highly myopic and highly myopic eyes relative to normative data bases.

A large group of investigators and studies have contributed to the development of topographically-correspondent structural abnormality detection.1,44,105,124-138 An important goal of our paradigm is to detect and characterize ONH and pPole structural abnormality in a topographically correspondent fashion (Figure 12) so as to improve their clinical characterization through the full spectrum of myopia and glaucoma.

Both longstanding “Legacy” scan patterns (left) and new “Isotropic Posterior Pole” (pPole) scan patterns (for both structural and angiography analyses) (right) will be obtained on each study eye. (ONH-RC - optic nerve head (ONH) 48 radial and circular B-scans (at three locations) acquired relative to the FoBMO axis, centered on the BMO centroid); (pPoleH - serial horizontal B-scans acquired parallel to the FoBMO axis); (pPoleV – serial vertical b-scans acquired perpendicular to the FoBMO axis.The GMOPC (www.gmopconsortium.org) is an investigator-initiated study that will, with the assistance of its industry partner, (Heidelberg Engineering), collect data from 13 international clinical sites to populate three new 360 subject study cohorts: Cohort 1 – highly myopic eyes without GLVFL; Cohort 2 - highly myopic eyes with GLVFL; and Cohort 3 – Non-highly Myopic eyes with early GLVFL (Figure 13).

GMOPC OCT data acquisition will occur relative to the FoBMO axis using a next generation OCT instrument that includes high-speed eye-tracking, high-speed OCT A-scan acquisition, expanded refractive error correction and increased axial data collection to optimize posterior pole visualization in highly myopic eyes (Figure 14).

To lay the foundation for international longitudinal studies in glaucoma and myopia.OCT parameterization of pNC-SB, alone, will not adequately detect and characterize myopic staphylomatous degeneration (Figure 15).

When there is a region of exposed scleral flange tissue internal to the ASCO, the SFO can be manually segmented either “geometrically” when identifiable (Panels B2 and C2) or “estimated” by visually projecting the anterior laminar surface through the neural canal wall (Panel A2). (A3 – C3) The slope of the anterior scleral flange surface (between the ASCO and SFO) can be calculated in a manner that is separate from, but complimentary to, the pNC-SB-SS parameter (Figure 5.The pNC-SB parameters of this report characterize bowing of the pNC-sclera (i.e., the juxta-canalicular sclera immediately peripheral to the ASCO), but do not capture bowing of the neural canal scleral flange, when this form of myopic ONH remodeling is present (Figure 15).

OCT characterization of neural canal scleral flange bowing is a necessary next step towards parameterizing myopic staphylomatous degeneration and efforts to do so are underway in our laboratory.Supplementary Material

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

(A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4).

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42
Figure 4.
FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

Within the 3D point cloud of segmented points from each OCT ONH data set, (Figure 3), Bruch’s membrane and the anterior scleral surface points were interpolated using b-splines. pNC-CT was assessed in microns at six distances (vertical blue dotted lines) from the ASCO, measured within the ASCO reference plane, (horizontal blue dotted line).
To simplify data presentation, we concentrate on pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points (where they approximate the measurement of pNC-SS (see Figure 5).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

Maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-SB were increased and maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-CT were decreased within the inferior sectors of the highly myopic with GLVFL compared to the highly myopic without GLVFL eyes (Supplemental Figure 1) but these differences did not achieve statistical significance.

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

Figure 12 illustrates our conceptual framework for clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, structural abnormality detection in non-highly myopic and highly myopic eyes relative to normative data bases.

A large group of investigators and studies have contributed to the development of topographically-correspondent structural abnormality detection.1,44,105,124-138 An important goal of our paradigm is to detect and characterize ONH and pPole structural abnormality in a topographically correspondent fashion (Figure 12) so as to improve their clinical characterization through the full spectrum of myopia and glaucoma.

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

(A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4).

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42
Figure 4.
FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

Within the 3D point cloud of segmented points from each OCT ONH data set, (Figure 3), Bruch’s membrane and the anterior scleral surface points were interpolated using b-splines. pNC-CT was assessed in microns at six distances (vertical blue dotted lines) from the ASCO, measured within the ASCO reference plane, (horizontal blue dotted line).
To simplify data presentation, we concentrate on pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points (where they approximate the measurement of pNC-SS (see Figure 5).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).

To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

FoBMO orientation of the data is achieved by rotating the photo (8° counter clock-wise above and 10° clockwise below) so that the FoBMO axis, rather than the Acquired Image Frame ((AIF) - Blue outline –Figure 4), establishes the Nasal-Temporal and Superior-Inferior axes (shown for the healthy control eye, above, red dotted lines). (B) pNC-SB-ASCOD data for each eye schematically presented in eye-specific, (left eye above and right eye, below) FoBMO orientation. (C) pNC-SB-SS data for the inner (0-300), middle (300-700) and outer (700-1000) measurement segments presented schematically in FoBMO orientation. (D) Continuously plotted pNC-SB-SS data in FoBMO orientation. (E) and (F) pNC-CT data presented schematically (E) and continuously (F) relative to the FoBMO axis.

Note that while the sectoral differences in pNC-CT data are modest for the control eye (upper) and substantial for the highly myopic eye (lower), by inspection of the sectoral values, the inferior temporal regions demonstrate the greatest amount of pNC-SB and the thinnest pNC-CT for both the control and highly myopic eye.Figure 12.
